Now, i studied psychology at university, and i find the workings of the mind absolutely fascinating and criminal psychology is my bit thing BUT the childish, naval gazing bullsh*t we get subjected to in this story line took away from (rather than added to) my enjoyment of the book - sad seeing as it was the idea of the 2 being interspersed that initially attracted me to the book )o:Don't believe me - hmm, how about the pissing contest over something that happens to Dr. Freud? I choose those words advisedly, as Freud wets himself in the lobby of their hotel.....and what ensues is a deep analysis amongst his peers as to WHY Freud's bladder chose to let go then and there, why in public not private, why in the presence of those particular individuals? Oh for goodness sake chaps, GET OVER YOURSELVES!!!!!!So 3 stars because of the very enjoyable gothic mystery, tricky twists, and to the author for coming up with the most inventive way of bumping someone off in my recent memory (o:Read the mystery bits, and skim the Psychoanalysis parts!

The only problem I had with this book was the pacing. The plot twists were numerous and clever, but the way they were resolved at the end felt a little hasty. Perhaps, if I were smarter, I'd have been able to keep up, but I felt that the elegant pacing of the first few chapters was unduly thrown aside in favor of a more helter-skelter plunge towards the end.That said, I was pleasantly surprised by how the plot twists kept me surprised almost to the very last. Jed Rubenfeld does a great job of sticking closely to the source material while introducing fictional elements. Characterization felt a little thin in places, probably due to the breakneck speed with which so much was introduced, but Littlemore, in particular, is someone I'd like to read more of. The book was also a fascinating glimpse into the dynamic between Freud and Jung, and worthy reading for that alone.I did think Mr Rubenfeld's analysis of Hamlet to be quite compelling, as was Younger's idea of the real meaning of the Oedipal complex. It would have been nice to find out the reasons behind Younger's father's death, but I think that's pretty much the only plot thread left dangling (depending, as well, on how much you read into Younger's conversation with Freud at the end.)Altogether, a compelling murder mystery that I would recommend for fans of the era and setting, as well as for those with a passing interest in the origins of psychoanalysis.

Murder mystery thriller set in early 1900s NYC including Freud and friends. Pacing is good. Historical research is good. Plot is convoluted, and if you think about it too hard at the end, you will find plot holes, and you will think it is dumb. One character randomly has 1st person narration, while the rest have 3rd, for no good reason. Everyone is not quite what they seem, except not so much. For example, the main detective is less dumb than he seems, which should be obvious if you read his dialogue. This tends to work better if you write the characters with a bit more depth, but of course that doesn't generally work with thriller stype pacing. B&D/S&M/prostitution, Freud's theories are central to the plot, though not making up the majority of the text. The explanation of Freud's theories is more nuanced than the sexuality of the characters. Also, the author wrote Jung as a big jerk. Would not recommend. Trying to be the Alienist, but not as good. First choice read should be that book, but would also rec. 'The Fig Eater' by Jody Shields or 'Maisie Dobbs' (the first book in the series) by Jacqueline Winspear instead.

The Interpretation of murder is a story shrouded in mystery, ill will, and love. It's about an up-and-coming detective pairing with a band of infamous psychiatrists and psychoanalysts such as Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung. This book is not your usual crime novel; it's synopsis does not do it justice. My initial reaction from reading this piece of literature was pure fascination. This novel has a multitude of stories within it; the plot divides into a number of miniature plots, each working to hook the reader deeper and deeper into the book. I was particularly interested in the "conflict" Freud creates against another character in the story. Also, the love angle of the story proves to be both entertaining and tragic. The cons of this story is the suspense of the novel; you can never tell exactly who's the bad guy. You can always muse about who's the real criminal, but you'll never understand the reason behind his/her motives until you read it yourselves. Also, the beginning of the novel is a bit slow in my opinion. However, when everything's in place, the book suddenly becomes incredibly compelling. Hope you enjoy reading it!

This is the first novel in a series by Jed Rubenfeld. His second, The Death Instinct, was a historical mystery thriller which I thoroughly enjoyed. So I decided to read his first, and I was not disappointed.Set in New York City in 1909, Rubenfeld introduces his main characters, NYC Police Detective Littlemore and a doctor in the new field of psychoanalysis, Stratham Younger, who is fascinated by the new theories of a doctor from Vienna, Sigmund Freud. According to the author, he based this novel around the fact that Freud did visit America in 1909 and upon leaving, made the comment that America was "a tragic mistake." While it's not know why Freud said that, Jed Rubenfeld hypothesizes on what Freud might have possibly seen and/or heard that would have made him say that.Rubenfeld writes in an entertaining and very readable style. He sets his murder-mystery around the sights and sounds, and famous people, of New York City in 1909. His descriptions of the city and its social classes make you feel like you are there. I can't wait for the next in this series.

(I was going to upgrade this to two stars on the well-researched historical basis but then I read the author's note that quite a lot of the "history" was stretched, relocated or simply invented to fit the story.) If you're looking for a thriller where Sigmund Freud rolls upo his sleeves to chase a murderer, look elsewhere; he's in his hotel room brtooding or suffering from bladder and digestive problems. His part is decidedly minor and really just part of a parallel story concerning Carl Jung and the early American history of psychoanalysis. If you're looking for a murder thriller with lots of twists and turns, set in early 20th century New York, read "The Alienist" by Caleb Carr. If you're looking for a fairly mundane and straightforward detective story with virtually no surprises, look no further. A lackluster and disappointing attempt, despite all the bells and whistles, unfortunately.

Oh god this was so awful The plot was badly constructed with endless stupid side plots that are half-assedly jumbled together at the end. It was deeply misogynistic the whole way through which is not surprising given it’s basically Freud fan fiction (why. Why did I read this?) but the sections on how Nora obviously must have been sexually excited by being assaulted as a fourteen year old was both unnecessary and disgusting. Parts of this read like an undergraduate thesis on Freud sandwiched between peculiar episodes of someone imagining what their psychologist heroes (plus some random useless extras) might be like if they got to hang out with them. Younger is a vile protagonist whose long creepy lingering descriptions of how much he wants to bang Nora make me feel as though the author has never actually met a woman in his life.I threw this book across the room and frankly I wish I’d thrown it out the window.

I really enjoyed this book, although I found myself getting bored by the Hamlet/pyschoanalysis parts when I first started it. After a while, I began to find Younger's Hamlet comments rather interesting, as I've read several Shakespearean plays, and had a giggle at Freud's pyschoanalysis as I quite frankly, thought that it was a load of crap. The mystery however, I really enjoyed. I thought I knew exactly what was going on but it turned out to be far more complex than I had expected. I think that Rubenfeld could become a great mystery writer - if he left out deep pyschoanalytic and literary-analysis comments, which many of us common people either don't understand or aren't interested in. I have a feeling that it is Freud and Younger's thoughts which have put people off this book. All in all, a fascinating and compelling read, one which I'm glad I chose on a whim. 9/10

It was a pretty interesting book and overall I liked it. It's almost half-biography/half-fiction, building a mystery around Freud's visit to America in 1909. However, Freud's presence was more of a backdrop and I don't think it was necessarily consequential to the story. Having said that, I appreciate that the author must have carried out a lot of painstaking research and it was interesting to read his Author's Note at the end, to see where fiction and fact meet. I think that the fictional parts of the book were the strength, particularly the characters the author invented. Hugel, Nora, Younger and especially Littlemore provided many humorous and touching moments. I felt the explanation of the mystery was a tad convoluted but it was a satisfying read and I also enjoyed the analysis of Hamlet that ran through the book.

I thoroughly enjoyed this "summer mystery read" that I picked up on a book swap table in our first apartment in Paphos. It is intelligent and licentious, clever and outrageous, historical with obvious fictionality. I'm not well studied on Freud or Jung (my main connections to them have been via lit crit), but I think their characters and positions were portrayed in an interesting way, and felt familiar but fresh. I particularly liked the author (and protagonist's) interest in Shakespeare, especially Hamlet and the connection to psychoanalysis and the crime(s). Good stuff. Well written, and there is something fascinating about New York in the early 1900s. Not to mention the criticism of America, and how what happened in the past still influences today. See esp. Freud's comments on America as well as the neurologists comments on psychoanalysis.

Seemingly mixed reviews below... Firstly this book was not what I expected. Secondly this does not make it a bad thing. I have an understanding of Freud's work and suggestions and maybe that allowed me to read the book in a different way. It was a little slow to start, but essentially this becomes a murder mystery over a book about Freud, and that is what draws you in. There's a nod to those damned 50 shades of grey books in here, possibly more so than is required, but following the aetiology if Freud it's needed and is what makes this book so good on that level. Worst case scenario is read it and enjoy it - u don't have to take something away from every single book you read, but I did. So thanks Jed Rubenfeld

While the reference to real events have been woven into a fictional thriller quite creatively and some of the early 20th century facts about New York’s Elite and discussions between Freud and Jung were really interesting, the thriller itself is quite predictable and can't even compare with the best 'Law and Order' episodes. The author seems to be in awe of Freud yet he goes about dissecting his 'Oedipus' analysis minutely and can't seem to figure out whether to agree or disagree with it for the most part and finally decides to take a contrary view triggered by a Hamlet obsession. (!?), taking the conclusion of an otherwise interesting analysis into a bit of an overreach.

There is a growing genre of novels set around psychological and psychiatric circumstances at the beginning of the era of mind discernment that contain a mix of real elements and real individuals as well as the driving force of the thriller...this is such a story...set in 1909 on the occasion of Sigmund Freud's only visit to America and the possibility that a sexual sadist-serial killer is at large and at work. The book is one of those marvelous examples of social history, historical who-dunnit and essay cum story assessment of psychological reasoning. It's fast paced, a neat portrait of New York and a not bad thriller

The author uses the historical visit by Sigmund Freud to the U.S. in 1909, and develops a mystery and characters to create this story. Freud and Carl Jung, who accompanied Freud on this visit, bicker about their differences in regard to psychoanalysis, and personality development. Freud attempts to help the New York city police solve some murders of young women, using his theories of the Oedipal Complex. A young American therapist is the central figure in the story, and has his own theories that differ from Freud's. I enjoyed the historical setting and detail, and the interesting mystery.

I have a mixed opinion about this book. On the one hand, it was an excellent murder mystery. I was constantly changing my mind about who did it and trying to pick up clues along the way. It pulled me in right up to the end when I discovered that not only was I wrong about who did it but exactly what was done.But, I felt that the book had way too many characters. My reading was prolonged because I was constantly trying to figure out who was who and how they fit in. And I have to admit that I got real tired real fast of the Frued/Jung storyline.

A beautiful cover, two interesting stories coming together,history, crime and Freud, These are the things that made this clever story into a joy to read. I am saying clever because till the end, many people seemed to be involved or guilty of many different things but only at the end the truth became clear and was again different of what it seemed! And so well written that you are absorbed by it.I am not sure how to explain but the way this book was written, the story was told felt new, different.

I am somewhat ambivalent about this story. It was a good read from a historical perspective, but the plot did not move me in regards to the mystery. Reviewers love this book because of its plotting -- the red herrings, the mistaken identities, etc. It is therefore ironic that these literary "tools" are why I dislike the story -- the descriptive words seem to drive the story rather than the ACTION words.Also, having characters like Freud and Carl Jung just did not do it for me. I might have enjoyed this more if I had a deeper appreciation for these scientists.

What I really liked about this novel is the background on Freud and psychoanalysis - it's history, science, and early application. Rubenfeld gave a good study of this subject and at the same time built a good mystery around it. Then to add to that, there is the protagonist's grappling with famous literatures - Hamlet and Oedipus Rex - as he helps solve the mystery. A lot of things goes on in this novel and yet everything works together to create a plausible and gripping story. The setting was also fascinating. New York in the beginning of the 20th century is a story on its own.

An intersection of psychology, literature and murder set in Manhattan in 1909, The Interpretation of Murder intersects the lives of larger than life influential figures with those of fictitious characters who play out the interpretations of reality that new theories present. By intensifying these intersections through a few minor manipulations of time, Jed Rosenfeld brings diverse interpretations from ancient times in line with the most modern manifestations of human behaviour. Our choices and consciousness are delivered back into our own hands. What will we do with it?

An artful construct, blending fact and fiction, as the novel is set against last-century New York, while the murders of the title are partly solved through the psychological ponderings of Freud, Jung, et al! The birth of psychological profiling in murder cases, perhaps.The prose is at times slightly turgid in my view, despite the regular shifts of perspective relating to the protagonist, Younger, ie, from 1st to 3rd person, to keep the reader on their toes!

The novel is set during the one and only visit of Sigmund Freud to America. Apparently, for the rest of his life Freud referred to Americans as "savages" and spoke disparagingly of the US. It's a true historical mystery, because no one knows what may have happened while Freud was here that so soured the man on this country and its people...Loved the detailed description of 1909 New York, and the way some basic principles of psychoanalysis was explained - this is a well researched book!

Though I didn´t find it that great and not deserving all the hype surrounding it, I enjoyed it mainly for the way Jed Rubenfeld portrayed New York in the beginning of the 20th century. It was magnificently done and it was what pleased me most. As for the Freud parts and the murders mystery, it was somewhat boring. Nonetheless, if you enjoyed " The Alienist" or " The Dante Club" give it a try and I think you will share my opinion - a so-so book, not bad not great

The end of this book redeemed it slightly, but I still wasn't a fan in general. I didn't like the writing style at all: some first person, but quite a lot not; the viewpoint changed every few paragraphs at times making it feel a bit all over the place to me. And on top of this, as a psychologist I just couldn't take the whole Freud/psychosexual thing seriously.The worst part? I now have to read the sequel for my book club *sigh*

This is one of the best books I've ever read, a really enchanting, complex, thrilling and intelligent novel which describes New York in 1909 in a most vivid detail... It's also one of the most cleverly plotted murder mysteries I've ever encountered. I love it! This is one of the wonderful pressie books from Cornwall. Thank you Captain GG and Johnny!!

If you are curious about the world of psychotherapy and its orgins / the response it received from the world then pick up this book. Although it is not very factually correct it does give a wonderful representation of the era. Also contains an interesting interpretation of Shakespeare's Hamlet.

I found the beginning of this book quite boring -- it's well researched, I think, and the descriptions are vivid, but I just didn't get into it. I didn't get close to the characters or feel particularly excited about the plot. Doesn't help that I'm not terribly interested in Freud and his theories -- books where famous writers are the detectives are much more in my line.

Chosen at random from my Dad's bookshelf, as had forgotten to bring another book to read this weekend. He said he didn't like it.Now I've finished it....that's a very apt rating. "It was OK". It took a long time to get going, I didn't really like the analysts, and really only got into the book in the last quarter where the action started to hot up.Dad was right.

I totally loved this book. Intrigue, murder, mystery, psychoanalysis & Shakespeare all in one place make it unputdownable. The lead characters are so likeable you fear for their lives & long for a good outcome for them. I would like to read more books by Jed Rubenfeld as this book was a pleasure to read. I can highly recommend it.
Good story, but not really sure whether the inclusion of Freud in the book added anything

I did enjoy this story. It reminded me of the book we read about Chicago. In the middle it got a little drawn out as to the possibilities of the murderer, but in the end the authornwraped it all up neatly.

BBC blurb - Adaptation of the crime thriller, in which psychoanalyst Sigmund Freud is drawn into a murder investigation in New York. Read by William Hope and Martin T Sherman15 episodes spread over TOO long a time period - bad bbc!

It was well written and all, but it just couldn't keep my interest up. Probably just me. Not sure what it was, but I could only stay interested every 5 pages or so, and kept falling asleep while I was reading. Had really hoped I'd like it, but...

I feel this book will need a second reading if I can make myself start it! I enjoyed the crime parts got a bit lost in the detail of psycho analysis, found the details of the setting detracted from my enjoyment - you could almost get so lost you forgot the plot - or perhaps that was the plot!

Very nice historical fiction /murder mystery. I loved the very factual parts of the book and enjoyed discovering exactly how much was taken from history.I would recommend to any murder mystery fans and those historical fiction fans who don't mind a little bit of violence.

I have mixed feelings about this book. It took several chapters for me to be vested in this novel, but towards the end I enjoyed the plot twists. I think this would make an intriguing play more so than a movie.

I struggled to get started with this book. I struggled to get quite into it. But once I did, I sure as hell did not struggle to finish it. I must admit I enjoyed the delving into Freud's analyses and the history far more than the murder mystery.

Lots of interesting facts about early 20th century New York City in this book. Freud and Jung are intertwined throughout the book, and some of the psychology was a bit heady for me. I will try reading another one of Rubenfeld's books, as I've heard anything he writes is good.
The most witty composition I have read so far. A stunning story that keeps you on your toes till the very end. And if thats not enough, the end that changes the world upside down...
Loved reading this book!Maybe not the most incredible writing and at times it was a tad slow but I truly enjoyed it. Maybe because I have a secret crush on Freud. :)
Loved this book. Can't remember the last time I was so engrossed in a novel! Oh wait - I can. It was "the Secret History" by Donna Tartt...
Interesting situation more than anything. Freud in New York and a society murder. Worth a go.
Mixed feelings about this book - there were parts where it was completely suspenseful and thrilling to read. At times I just felt bored and confused...
I really good book with great plot and characterization. Must read for a thrill lover. Hope he would have written more books.
4.5. Great gem that I found at a used bookstore last week. Would appeal to readers that appreciated "Devil in the White City" and "The Alienist".

Jed Rubenfeld is a modern-day Renaissance man. A professor of law at Yale University who has also taught at Stanford and Duke, he is an expert on constitutional law, privacy and the First Amendment. He studied theatre and Shakespeare at Julliard and wrote a thesis on Sigmund Freud during his senior undergraduate year at Princeton. He is also the author of six books, two of which are novels. It seems as though there’s nothing he can’t do. If I didn’t admire him so much, I’d be horribly jealous. (Well, maybe I can do both at the same time.)The Interpretation of Murder was his first novel. It’s a very intricate weaving of true events and characters with fictional events and characters. Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, Sandor Ferenczi, Ernest Jones, Abraham Brill – all real life figures in the early 1900s movement of psychoanalysis, which was new, controversial and in competition with neurology – mingle with the fictional Elizabeth Riverford, Dr Stratham Younger, Nora Acton, George and Clara Banwell, Coroner Hugel and Detective Littlemore. There’s a miniature essay at the end of the book clearly outlining what’s real and what’s not and the artistic licence taken, which is a good thing because the blending of them is seamless.When Elizabeth Riverford is murdered in an apartment at the exclusive Balmoral building in New York, Coroner Hugel and Detective Littlemore are assigned to investigate the case. On the same night as her death, Dr Stratham Younger meets Dr Sigmund Freud as he steps off the George Washington steamship for what is his first (and turns out to be his last) trip to the US. Dr Freud is there to advance the cause of psychoanalysis through a series of university lectures and Dr Younger is one of his American devotees.Later the same week, Nora Acton is apparently targeted by Elizabeth Riverford’s killer but survives when the murderer is disturbed. Miss Acton is unable to remember who attacked her and has lost her voice to boot. When Dr Younger hears about the case at a society event, he volunteers Dr Freud’s talents in order to help the debutante recover both her memories and her ability to speak. Knowing he will be in the country a short time and that recovery could take a while, Dr Freud appoints Dr Younger to perform the psychoanalysis.Coroner Hugel determines conclusively that whoever killed Elizabeth Riverford is the same person who attacked Nora Acton and when, after a few sessions With Dr Younger, she identifies George Banwell as her assailant, it seems like case closed. Except for one thing. George Banwell, a wealthy property developer married to Miss Acton’s best friend, has an airtight alibi for the time of Elizabeth Riverford’s murder. He was dining outside of the city with New York Mayor, George McClellan. It’s a head scratcher. And when Miss Riverford’s body goes missing from the morgue, it becomes difficult to prove there ever was a murder, let alone a murderer.It’s not a straightforward murder mystery. Jed Rubenfeld, through his main character of Dr Stratham Younger, delves into the real life history of the tumultuous relationship between Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung, the true meaning of “to be or not to be” in Hamlet and alternative theories of what the Oedipus complex actually means. It’s mostly superfluous to the plot and while I found it fascinating, I can understand that some might not.In the end, the plot turns out to be a little bit convoluted but it almost doesn’t matter. The writing is wonderful and the research impeccable. New York just after the turn of the twentieth century is a character all on its own, beautifully portrayed and perfectly used. Along with society matriarchs, rebellious daughters, immoral fathers, psychotic psychiatrists, corrupt officials, madams and prostitutes with hearts of gold, and determined discoverers of the truth, it all makes for an intriguing set of circumstances. Because even the fictional people feel real.It took me a while to read this book but unlike some others that seem to drag on and on, I really didn’t mind. I could have happily spent a lot longer engrossed in its pages. And I imagine that it’s the sort of book that you could get more and more out of on second and subsequent readings and also the kind of book that different people could take different things from. I don’t know that it’s destined to become a classic but it sure was enjoyable while it lasted.

I picked up The Interpretation of Murder by Jed Rubenfeld at the book exchange at my local train station. Having just finished it today, I'm very conflicted about it, since I really enjoyed it, whilst at the same time finding its treatment of, presentation of and attitudes towards women absolutely appalling.I do like the premise - a gap in the historical records of Freud's trip to America and a seemingly unreasonable attitude of Freud's towards America after this trip. The book seeks to propose what may have happened during the trip to upset him so much. However, the main plot of a young psychoanalyst being asked to consult on a murder actually has very little to do with Freud, and the subplot about the threat to Freud's lecture series at an American university has no real connection to this main plot thread, so seems a bit by the by.The way the story comes together is clever, if rather too convoluted for my taste, and the writing is pacy and compelling. Though, at least to begin with, the author seems very keen for the reader to know just how much research he's done into the society and geography of New York in 1909, including large passages of exposition and description.And so on to the women... They are dismissed, mocked, disparaged or objectified throughout. Even the coroner's reaction to the corpse at the start is couched in terms of her beauty, which is a bit icky. The protagonist falls in love with his 17-year-old patient. And, when she tells him she's gay, his response is to try to kiss her. I hate the way their relationship progresses and ends up, particularly with her incredibly convenient 18th birthday...The point of view shifts in the narrative are also a bit offputting. Dr Younger gets a first person POV, but also appears as a character in some of the third person perspective scenes, and the number of POV characters overall gets a bit too many towards the end.There's basically only one character in the whole thing who isn't awful, and that's Detective Littlemore, who at least treats everyone with due respect, is actually nice to people, and manages to get leads in the case by doing good deeds and keeping to his principles. So, it seems like the author know what a good person is - he just decided to make most of his characters terrible for some reason.There's a lot of monologuing to explain everything at the end, which is always a bit tiresome, and there were so many twists to the story that it was difficult to follow in some parts of the explanation.So, it's really sounds like I didn't enjoy it at all - but I did, for some reason! It kept me interested all the way through and I was very keen to find out how it would all work out in the end. So, a bit baffled by my response to this one!

This historical fiction mystery involving Sigmund Freud's 1909 trip to the USA left me feeling ambivalent. If I had been reading it instead of listening to a CD in my car, I doubt I would have finished it. It was just too long and tiresome. I have read at least one book about Freud and have an educated person's working knowledge of his theories. I have read Hamlet three or four times. I've read entertaining historical fiction and nonfiction about this era in New York. All of these have interested me greatly. This book is not without merit: At times, the story and characters are engaging. At times, the discussions about psychoanalysis and among psychoanalysts were interesting. But there was way too much of this in the book to support the mystery. Throughout the book, there were bizarre resolutions and incidents that were just not believable or did not fit. More could have been done to make these fit in. They made for distracting instead of satisfying reading. I knew fairly early on which character was responsible for most of the bad behavior. I found I didn't like any of the female characters, which makes me suspicious of the author's perception of women, but then, just barely liked one or two of the male characters. A lot of work went into the book, but much of it should have been parked in another book or on the cutting room floor. Let go of Hamlet! Cut out and edit the extraneous characters and factoids you just couldn't bear to leave out. Eliminate one whole red herring that simply didn't work. Incorporate the other red herrings more seamlessly. Drop the bad guy club and the details about Jung and Freud and the other psychoanalysts. Their roles could have been more deftly written. There may be two books here that could include some of what I'd cut from the mystery.

I LOVED this book. When I pulled it off the shelf at a thrift store years ago and saw "Manhattan, 1909" on the back cover, I knew I had to buy it. Yes, it took me a few years to get to (I have nearly 3000 books on my shelves right now), but it was a GREAT book. In addition to the main plot and history that it includes, I LOVED the discussions about "Hamlet," which I have taught many times and which is my favorite play. I'm not sure that I agree with the narrator's (and, I assume, author's) interpretation of "To be or not to be," but I still loved reading it and all of the discussion leading up to it.I'm not going to rehash the plot. No need; there's a summary up above. But I will say that I would recommend it to anyone who loves1) turn-of-the-century New York City,2) historical fiction in general,3) murder mysteries,4) Freud, Jung, and all aspects of psychology, psychiatry, and analysis, and5) "Oedipus" and "Hamlet."Did I mention 1909 Manhattan? Gramercy Park, Mayor McClellan, the police department, Lexington Ave., the Players Club, Coney Island, hotels, Manhattan Bridge, Harry Thaw, and other notables of the time.I have only one question, but I will ask that separately. Now I'm going to read other readers' reviews. I may be back with additional comments. :)Ok, I looked at a few reviews. Hmm. One complained that there was too much history and not enough fiction. The main characters (Younger, Littlemore, and Nora, not to mention both Banwells and Hugel) as well as the crimes depicted were all fictional. That was good enough for me. And I loved the way the real characters were worked into the novel. Yes, there were a lot of subplots and red herrings, but I found all of them interesting.

Talk about twists and turns. Jed Rubenfeld's book reads not only part essay but also part mystery, talking about Freud's only trip to America and applying Freud's psychoanalysis theory to the mystery itself. The characters themselves were interesting to read about. Seeing and reading about Freudian theory through the eyes of Younger was refreshing and offers a new way of understanding the man's ideas. I would have to say, however, that the moments were Rubenfeld delves such theories are at times heavy enough to slow down the pacing of an otherwise thrilling mystery. Undoubtedly, though, such passages are well-researched. Overall, the beginning was a bit hard for me to get through. As said before, the psychology parts were enough to slow down the pacing, so much so that I had to put it down and pick it up the next day. However, after reaching the 100s, the pacing ramped up, and I couldn't stop reading until the very end. Finally, the mystery's conclusion was unexpected. Not so much for Clara (I felt it either had to be her or her husband, and I ended up with both!), but for Hugel. The coroner's introduction had me thinking that he was an uptight but righteous man. Incorruptible. Yet, in the end, I find out that he was an accomplice, a man capable of being bribed just like all those corrupt officers Hugel himself hated. I should have suspected something was up when Hugel gave up on the case so readily, but I never actually thought he could be a part of the crime. I saw that Jed Rubenfeld wrote a sequel to this book, and I will be eagerly picking that one up. Hopefully, he writes more - I truly enjoy his writing!

Overall the book is undeniably a good murder mystery, with several suspects and a few plot twists. However, Freud is a very marginal character in the story, barely being involved with the main story line and mostly being discussed in regards to the developments surrounding the translation of his work into English and the introduction of psychoanalysis to American doctors. As it was maybe to be expected, Freud's Oedipal complex is widely discussed and integrated in the main plot. What I found especially inappropriate and frankly disgusting was the application of the Oedipal complex in regards to all of Nora's (the surviving victim) experiences. The particular instance where it is stated that she "obviously must have been excited" when she was assaulted at only fourteen years old was genuinely appalling and unnecessary. In addition, whilst Nora is thoroughly analysed and judged throughout the book, not one attempt is made to analyse the assailant nor there is any judgement towards the atrocities he commits.Furthermore, as much as I appreciate this work is historical fiction, and the characters' opinions are mainly supposed to be in line with the mentality of the time, the amount of misogynistic and racists remarks throughout the entire book did bother me. In conclusion, despite the mystery itself being very intriguing, the book comes across as very misogynistic and often racist, and the integration of Freud's theories in the plot felt forced and often extremely inappropriate. Unfortunately, in this case the intriguing mystery is not enough to outweigh the bad, reason why I would not recommend this book unless you are a die-hard fan of Freud's work and are not bothered by all the aforementioned issues.

"On the morning after Sigmund Freud arrives in New York on his first - and only - visit to the United States, a stunning debutante is found bound and strangled in her penthouse apartment, high above Broadway. The following night, another beautiful heiress, Nora Acton, is discovered tied to a chandelier in her parents' home, viciously wounded and unable to speak or to recall her ordeal. Soon Freud and his American disciple, Stratham Younger, are enlisted to help Miss Acton recover her memory, and to piece together the killer's identity. It is a riddle that will test their skills to the limit, and lead them on a thrilling journey - into the darkest places of the city, and of the human mind."Well researched in terms of the geography of New York at the time, fact and fiction intertwined, with a little time fiddling here and there. The concept is solid, but instead of the gripping thriller one expects from the 'blurb', what one receives is an overcomplicated and tedious novel, in which Freud features very little, and which zips back and forth between the first and third person faster than Mo Farah can run the 100 meters. I found this so hard to get into, it started unbelievably slowly and didn't pick up pace much throughout. I did enjoy, however, the character of Jimmy Littlemore, who added a touch of comedy to an otherwise rather dull effort. Sorry to say not a favourite for me, rather disappointing given the hype, but cleverly put together and exceptionally researched. Hats off to Rubenfeld for managing so many insanely complex characters all at once!

I’m enamored with New York City and suffer endless fascination with the historical architecture. When the author states specific addresses and landmarks such as Gramercy Park, Lexington Avenue it’s easy for my minds eye to travel there placing me in the story imagining what it could of looked like in 1909. It feels like there is many stories wrapped up into this novel. A murder, Freud & Jung’s relationship, Hamlet, corruption in the local government & police and the struggle of accepting psychoanalysis/therapy as a valid treatment. All these topics wind around each other and intersect telling a great story. There is a question posed by the author regarding Freud and his distaste for America. He refused to visit ever again after this trip in 1909. One line near the end of the book reads “this country of yours: I’m suspicious of it. Be careful. It brings out the worst in people - crudeness, ambition, savagery. There is too much money.” Sometimes I myself (Jennipher) sees this, especially in the last while when we felt so divisive. Even when I initially arrived to the US from Canada I felt fierce competitiveness here. Can we turn this into a force for goodness? Maybe it motivates individuals to create a better America. One where all feel safe, respected & empowered to help one another.

The book started strongly, sucking one straight into the story of a young American Freudian psychoanalyst, who gets involved in a case where someone is whipping and murdering beautiful young women. One such high society beauty escapes with her life and becomes our psychoanalyst's (Dr. Younger) patient. High society cover-ups, a coroner looking for advancement, a young police detective looking for his big break, a mayor trying to balance many interests while trying to get reelected...all coincide with Drs Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung and associates very first visit to USA. Freud gets peripherally involved in the case as Dr Younger's mentor. The dynamics among the group of psychoanalysts, especially between Freud and Jung, are depicted interestingly. Till half way the book keeps one's attention tautly engaged but begins to meander into too many side roads. And the final reveal is very convoluted. Found myself wishing the author would just finish.

This is fascinating. Ostensibly a murder tale, it covers a wide swath of themes: New York high society, the arguments between Freud and Jung, a discussion on the various interpretations of Hamlet and his "to be or not to be" speech, Oedipus, and Sappho. Just a really interesting book, with plenty of red herrings and fun. There's one bit where I shouted at the author for tricking me!I was wondering whether the author just loved psychoanalysis so much this was used as an experiment in whether this could be used academically in a mystery. It will keep you engaged and thinking as you go on.As it was, the intellectual approach to solving the mystery nicely dovetails into the basic police procedural work, and there is a delightful episode with one of the doctors and the police detective working on getting a clue in a caisson used to build the Manhattan Bridge, as water floods in...So all in all, possibly not everyone's cup of tea, but worth sticking with past the first 50 pages.

I'm having a really hard time giving this book a rating. I genuinely liked the plot of the book and it started out well but for many many chapters, reading it became painstakingly boring. The book only picked it up again towards the last few chapters with lots of twists that I really enjoyed and did not see coming. The writing style is very easy to follow and the imagery Rubenfeld created is amazing. He was able to bring 1909 New York vividly into life. I liked 3 characters, Freud, Littlemore, and Younger. Littlemore and Younger make such an amazing detective duo. I also really enjoyed Freud's analysis of almost everything in the book and I just find his views very interesting. I think one of the strongest points of this book is arguably the weakest as well. I really like how much research went into this but at times, it no longer felt like I was reading a book of fiction.

As many others have said, I found the book intriguing to start with. Once I got myself round the idea that Freud et al. were characters in this book.Though after reading halfway through and waiting for the multitude of plot lines to go somewhere, I lost interest in this book. It was almost all history and little fiction and the elements of fiction there was seemed a bit glib. I kept reading that next chapter in the hope the whodunits would finally be resolved and no, it just piled on with so much character depth yet no story. The best bit was where he describes "to be or not to be" and I actually learned that contrary to what I'd always thought, the 'to be' was not the positive, it was 'to be (silent), i.e. inept' and so what we'd actually all want to be is the 'not to be'. That sounds confusing, but hey.I'm so pleased I'm not alone in feeling this book went nowhere.

They say, don't judge a book by its cover, and yet I did. I picked it out of the rack and it promised all kind of intrigues and mystery seeing the reviews on the back. I guess it does when you can actually understand the theological bits of the conversations and the back and fort in references in the book. I can appreciate the research that went into writing this book and the story line itself, but I just did not connect to the characters. I also read this book in english, which is not my mother tongue, which might have contributed to my confusion about their conversations. I therefore skimmed through the pages, grabbing the essence of the story (which I liked - the twists and turns are numerous), getting to the conclusion of the book rather quickly. The ending did not dissapoint. The journey towards it was just nut my cup of tea.

A very twisted mystery combining elements of Freud, Shakespeare, Jung, and of course American History. This is not an easy mystery to read. There are many twists here. The plot and characters are suitably twisted and convoluted. In the end it all makes sense, as really good mysteries do. Readers be warned. There is also a disturbing scene involving a carriage horse, that highlights the evilness and power of one man.New York city in 1909, the year my father was born. I especially enjoyed the details, the people and the environment that made this mystery enjoyable. The characters are of course very interesting. It is a solid fact that Sigmund Freud and followers visited the city during 1909. What follows in the story is an alternative representation of this visit.

This book is set around several real historical set-pieces, such as Dr Freud's visit to New York in 1909. A woman is found strangled to death in her room with lacerations on her body. Dr Freud's fictional follower Dr Younger gets entangled with the mystery when another girl is attacked in a similar way and he is called on to psychoanalyse her.The plot unfolds, and at times it seems contrived and unclear. The mystery reveals itself in the end, and there are unexpected revelations. However, at times I was at a loss as to what was going on.Also, there is some material on psychoanalysis and Hamlet that people who are interested and versed in the subjects more than I am would enjoy a lot more. Nevertheless, this is a page-turner and definitely a unique story.

I give it a B+.I really, really enjoyed this book. But I found it more interesting than effective as a mystery. Rubenfeld fascinates with the back story he lays down concerning the new thinking in psychology that Freud and Jung are just in this time propelling with such force and vigor. These provide a wholly new way of thinking about the pathology of the criminal at work in the crimes that drive the story.But ultimately the back story is not served by the real story of the crimes, their investigation and their solution. That front story, if you will, is a bit thin.I’m very eager to read anything else Rubenfeld writes. His erudition, as a Yale legal scholar first trained in psychology and drama, shows on every page here.

Really good premise: during Freud's trip he gets pulled into a murder investigation, and has to use psychoanalysis to solve the crime. In many ways it's very similar to The Hound of the Baskervilles, starring Freud as Sherlock Holmes and one Dr. Younger as Dr. Watson. The execution was good, but not brilliant. In the end I didn't feel that the promise of the novel was really fulfilled; although psychoanalysis and oedipal complexes were major component of the crimes' solution, in the end they weren't as important as plain old detection. I think I would've liked it more if it had turned out that Freud was the puppet master all along and everyone had acted exactly as his theories would predict.

It was different. A murder mystery with a history of Freudian psychology thrown in. I really enjoyed the mystery of the book and the detective in the center of it (Detective Littlemore is a lovable and wonderful character). I thought the storyline of Freud and his acceptance in America was just eh. It desperately wants to be a part of the mystery, but falls short in that regard. I can see what the author was trying to do, but it didn’t work for me. But the actual mystery in the center of the book was fantastic. It had my favorite thing: an unexpected twist! Reflecting on it, I would say that I sort of saw it coming, but it was great. It could be that I was so unimpressed with the whole Freud thing that I was just happy to have another aspect of the book to keep me interested.

A thrilling murder mystery set in New York at the beginning of the 20th century. The best book I have read in a long time, I could not put it book down! Although the main plot is fiction, the author's in-depth knowledge of the cultural context is evident. This novel opened my eyes to a number of pressing issues, including racism, anti-semitism and female emancipation. Detailed descriptions of a number of Freud's psychoanalytic theories are also provided, while the tone is kept simple and accessible. I would highly recommend this book to anyone who enjoys murder mysteries, psychological thrillers, or would like to gain a better knowledge of what life was like on the east coast of the United States at the turn of the 20th century.

Spoiler AlertThe author has done an amazing job of capturing NYC around the early 20th century. That initially pulls you into the book and keeps one going. The use of Freud , Jung etc are just plot devices and any character could have been used ( :) true for most books ! I know). The ending is simply awful, almost feels like the author didn’t necessarily know how it needed to be finished or perhaps the planned finale never worked and was reworked badly ( closed rooms with suddenly hidden passages, people hanging who are not really hanging etc etc). It’s a real kick in the guts to get to the end and realise all the ending does is reverse all you read and you are left with a book that captures NYC really well and that’s all. Wouldn’t recommend it.

I enjoyed the book I read called, The interpretation of murder, it sounds like a classic British detective movie from the 40s that i used to watch with my fiancee on youtube, it's amusing work, the style of writing attracts me, with such elegance and simplicity, the suspense seduce me till the last page. You never know what happens next. When Sigmund Freud visited the United States in 1909, a girl called Miss Riverford may be murdered or maybe not, can Detective Littlemore solve the mystery of this murder? to be or not to be is the question .The only witness Nora Action is discovered tied to a Chandler in her parents home but she forgot everything, can Dr Younger help to recover her memory?This magnificent book leads us to the dark side of the human mind.

Can't quite put my finger on it, but I didn't really like this that much. It took me forever to get through it. I had a hard time keeping characters straight. I did wonder if Nora, was patterned on Freud case study of Dora, which I'd read in the 70's. I had a friend whose sister made a film about that. I'm interested to learn more about Jung, who I found to be thoroughly obnoxious in this book. For as much as Freud changed the world of analysis, it doesn't seem like many of his theories hold water today, but he did get the ball rolling, and I do think there is a lot to be said for the mind screwing up the body!

The story gets to elevated heights in certain places, where you just can't allow yourself to drop the book down. Sadly, those few are the only places where I got the feeling. The promises which these few places give are compromised throughout the other parts of the book. Way too much characters, Little or no characterization(Mind it. You just forget the person's story when you come across the name some 300 pages later). Had the author failed to include the insights on Freud and his theories, this book would have been a blunder mistake. Overall when you close the book and ponder, these few points makes this book a one time read.

I really wanted to like this book, because murders and psychology are like my favourite combination ever. But well, I didn't. There were too many subplots and too many characters. I kept on losing track of all of them, and had to go back again and again, until I completely lost interest and stopped doing even that. This book felt like a textbook to me, and not a story book. I stuck through the last few chapters only because I wanted to know who the murderer was, and wasn't really ENJOYING the book. This book is a well researched piece of work though, I'll have to appreciate the author for that. Hoping I'll enjoy this book after a reread (not anytime soon though).

Looked forward to the hype but it was a disappointing read.I found this book a slog to get through. Not a difficult read but just not interesting enough to want to keep picking it up. The story line was very slow with a dull almost pointless plot and the characters were unrelatable. It took most of the book to even get off the ground then tied everything up in a sudden abrupt ending. I found the interpretation of the psychologists was very simplistic and poorly executed. Throwing references to Hamlet into the story didn’t add anything either. I nearly gave up on this book a number of times. Quite frankly I am surprised I finished reading it.

I can highly recommend this book to anyone else who has attempted to read primary texts of Freud only to come away from that with more questions than answers. This novel spells out an interpretation (yes...) of his philosophy and also includes a vibrant and well-researched picture of New York City at the turn of the 20th century, but has one of the most convoluted mysteries I have ever read. Still even after the conclusion that was finally revealed and only slightly took away from the earlier narrative, I appreciated the digging into Freud and Jung's psychology from many different angles and helped me form my own conclusion on some of the theories I had been grappling with.

Just over 100 pages in and then I DNFed. I'm baffled by the reception of this book. I feel like every page left me with an eye roll at a cliche - language, characters, plot, they've a been done before and better.The use of real life characters was also more jolting that I'd considered it would be. Making historical figures into two-dimensional caricatures was very grating, and weirdly made the book read like historical fan fiction.The writing itself was bizarre - overly explicit descriptions and explanation which was clear by inference and didn't need to be said, and sections and chapters which led to nothing.Really not a fan of this one. Soz Richard and Judy.

I'm fascinated by Freud and his psychosexual theories, so I had high hopes for this book. I don't know if the author was just trying to show off his knowledge, but there are sections that are irrelevant and do little to progress the plot. There's some attempt to show early criminal profiling, but something just gets lost/confused in the translation. In some cases, the author's writing comes across as a bit misogynistic, even taking into consideration the time period of the novel. The overall plot is your typical thriller with a few red herrings thrown in. A good read, but I won't bother with the next one.

It is well-written and well-researched but feels too long and too ambitious. The main story is interesting and a classic murder mystery drama with a sprinkle of psychoanalysis, but the many side stories and characters make it long and convoluted. It was a struggle to have any feelings about any of the characters until the very end, when everyone's motives were revealed. The secondary storylines did not offer much, other than an excuse for the numerous characters to be there. I liked the detective part, as well as the psychoanalysis part, but would have liked to see the two blending together much earlier in the book and not in the last couple of chapters.

Couldn't put it down. Story very well paced. Thought the depictions of Freud and Jung and the tension between them was a powerful story in itself. The novice psychoanalyst and his therapeutic relationship with the mysteriously assaulted woman at the heart of the novel is well done with classic transference and countertransference issues interwoven skillfully with lots of edge of your seat tension. Evocation of early 19th century NYC is very involving with well balanced ingredients of corrupt politics, toxic religiousity, the depravity of some of the monied class, immigrant exploitation and, of course, murder.

This novel is set in New York at the turn of the 20th Century and weaves true historic data into a murder mystery story. The author takes a real visit to America by Sigmund Freud and a couple of his colleagues as the starting point to the story. I enjoyed the bits of the novel that describe the New York of that time as much as the actual story.It is a very enjoyable read, with lots of twits and turns. To be honest, if you stopped long enough to think too deeply about the story, there are probably lots of points at which you could think "this is not really plausible", but it keeps moving along and you get swept away with it. An entertaining read.

It was OK. Fell short of what I anticipated, though I had just come down from finishing Devil in the White City so perhaps the bar was too high, and this was too much fiction for me.In addition, there were lots of twists and turns that came about at the middle and end, almost too turbulent of a pace to keep up with. I honestly don't know why it got the acclaim it did. BUT, it was not a waste of time. There was a lot that fed my imagination and peaked my interest. Unlike other reads, I'm totally OK with moving on from this and am not craving for more.

This was a charity shop buy, I have never read anything by this author before so was an unknown quantity. However it turned out to be a really enjoyable informative read.The plot is full of twists and turns thrown in with lots of theories on physocoanalis from Sigmund Freud and his companions. I found most of the characters really likeable and especially the young police sergeant who i think was one of the pivotal characters, full of red herrings and kept me guessing till the end. In my opinion definitely worth a read

the interpretation of murder is an extremely cleverly written story involving the visit to America of Sigmund Freud and his beliefs of the Oedipus complex. Jed Rubenfelds ability to use his fascinating knowledge of Freud to write a truly unique and brilliant story is amazing. throughout the book Jed keeps the reader enthralled and wanting to read more of what is truly a brilliant storyline. well written, educational and brilliantly researched the interpretation of murder is a fascinating first book from Jed

I don't have a lot of respect to Freud's theories, especially in their more basic form. Therefore it was so intriguing to read a book where many characters treat his words as gospel as well as to see what arguments this theory brought in the academic world. As a mystery, this book is also good, with the main plot being slightly convoluted, but in an enjoyable way and having many, many red herrings. The social divisions of New York and, by extension, USA are nicely described and one can really feel the atmosphere of these times. A very nice read indeed.

This is simply a stunning masterpiece of fiction combined with fact. It pulled me in, sunk its teeth in me and refused to let go until I reached the end. Mystery, murder, intrigue, psychology,... Some books have IT and some books don't, and this book definitely has IT. I loved it from beginning to end. I thoroughly enjoyed the historical facts in it, and even more so enjoyed the murder mystery fiction part of it. And the way it all came together in the end was just pure icing on the cake. A brilliant, brilliant piece of writing indeed.

Very clever with lots of twists and turns (maybe just too many!). Rubenfeld has a clear writing style, suited to the theme of the novel, and evokes a fascinating picture of New York in 1909 - the building frenzy, the showy wealth and opulent life of the rich and well-to-do, with a glimpse of the grim underbelly, too. However, I was uncomfortable with the male dominance and emphasis on sex and sexuality. I understand that it all linked in with the work of Freud, and that society was male dominated at that time, but I just didn’t find it enjoyable.

It was alright. Entertaining but nothing that stands out. Have never read much of psychoanalysis or Freud so this was a first. To be honest did find it rather weird but it served a purpose. The writing itself was good and picturesque description of New York on the turn of the last century was rather romantic. I'm always a sucker for historical fiction. All three combined kept me going and I managed to finish it in one sitting. This would make a fine web series on Netflix or Hulu but that's about it

An unfortunate disappointment - this novel is a complete mess. Who is supposed to be the protagonist? Younger, Littlemore or Freud? And for that matter, what is Freud even doing there? I’m not sure the author knows. There are numerous incoherent plot threads, very clunkily tied up at the end. Add to this far too much exposition (we get it, the author did his research, but show don’t tell), as well as extremely two dimensional female characters (defined wholly by their appearance), and I was left with a flat and unfulfilling read.

loved this book, i did not know about Freud before this, i not most Academic person, this book challenged me mental in an interesting way that i found interesting amazing book really found it hard, which i loved really in joyed it and learn a lot.since reading you book really joyed reading it, v impress as author studied drama then did law. especial coming from a theatre, drama geek in the uk. its an excellent book but i like mystery and murder an thriller genera normal go to now as adult just like death instinct better. amazing book.

This book dragged on with too much discussions of Freud's Oedipus theories and Hamlet's meaning of "to be or not to be". These theories did little to move the plot along and could have been left out completely. I did enjoy it more when constable James Littlemore is on the scene the book moved along. The plot is quite convoluted with lots of twists and turns.I read this book after The Death Instinct, the sequel. I liked that book much better, not as much freudisms and more of Littlemore and Younger.

I certainly lost track of the plot at times, with some sections being overly long or unnecessary. Overall I enjoyed the edwardian setting and, having studied psychology, appreciated the background and history of early psychology woven throughout the storyline. I'd warn readers who are not familiar with Freudian psychology that his theories may seem distressing. Please be reassured that modern psychology has come a long way since then.Trigger warnings for domestic abuse, violence against women and outdated views on gender, due to the historical setting.

One long terrific novel to mess with the head. Freud would have laughed and admired by the work of Rubenfeld for utilising the concept of studying the unconscious mind with the interpretation of dreams20th century Manhattan, Sigmund Frued, Founder of Psychoanalysis, and a cold blooded murder. A book that will push you to the level where the reader can't rely on anything like the characters in the novel. P.S. Best psychological thriller for the unquenching grey cells.

In terms of writing and description, the book is fantastic and colourful. Not to mention the way psychology comes into this story. however, the plot is slow, dialogues not punchy enough to grab my attention and characters dont really stick to me. I do have to mention this book is not for everyone but, that doesn't mean you shouldn't try to read it. Coming from someone with a low attention span, this book didn't catch mine.

I came across this book in a second hand bookstore almost 10 years ago, and while I remember nothing at all about the plot except that Jung was in it, I still remember how wonderfully Rubenfeld bought the city and Jung to life. Rubenfield paints a rich, detailed and meticulously researched picture of New York at the turn of the century, and he peoples his city with an interesting cast of characters. I think it deserves a 4 star if only for that.

A multi-layer reading of psychology and detective fiction, inspired by Freud's concept and work.For me, I say it starts with a seemingly non-related streams of events and characters' storylines only to build up more suspension to the twist, then untie the knot in the most surprising manner, only to close the book with a satisfaction from both the surprise element and reasonably sufficient explanation. A worth reading piece 👌

This novel was a mini time travel machine. It took me on an intriguing journey through some of New York's 19th century societies. You get to explore Freud's psychoanalytic theories through Dr. Stratham Younger as he joins Detective Jimmy Littlemore to hunt down an elusive criminal while solving a number of strange crimes. Not sure the author (or should I say Dr. Younger) is a fan of Carl Jung. I enjoyed it.

Interesting but not gripping enough Sigmund Freud in person who tries to psychoanalyse a young woman and solve an intricated mystery looked an appealing cocktail, so I bought it. I took this book with me on the beach and read I over the weekend. It's an enjoyable read and you won't be disappointed if you read it with the right state of mind (you just want to spend the time while roasting in the sun). It's more of a 3.5 than a 3 star rating, but I gave 4 to more appealing novels than this one.

fantastic story, so interesting. Really well written and thought provoking.Not my usual fare but totally recommended!If you are interested in the history of early 20th Century America or psychoanalysis this will be such a good read. Its fiction but with a great deal of historical resonance. It looks well at how the puritanical background of America forged the early path and I thought that so super interesting.the end was just a little bit of a flaff

This book was not my cup of tea but deinately a must for psycological fans of Sigmund Freud himself considering his appearence in this book was definately exhilirating...furthermore the plot was not my thing but I overall like the aura of mystery created and the culprit in the end was deinately astonishing, there were graphic details that I do not prefer...But what I liked best was the character of the main protagonist not Sigmund Freud but Dr Stratham Younger!

When I saw this book on @thelittlestbookshopza I was fascinated and had to buy it. It looked like a blend of my favourite genres, historical fiction, crime and a dash of psychology. I just finished it, and while it took me a long time (I read slowly with 4 kids) I am impressed. I did not expect the twists and turns. It is marvelously executed and the Freudian insights throughout added a different slant. All in all, I think it’s a book that’s worth taking some time to read.

Monday evening book club choice. Well-researched and written historical crime fiction. Speculative fiction looking at tension between Freud and Jung, their theories, their differences and their own psychological tics. It's a bit longer than most of our book club choices, but it's a page turner so we flew through it. Although, feedback from the Book Club was mostly good, criticisms included that it's a bit sensational and a graphic at times.

I really enjoyed this. It was quite complex and involved a whole world with which I am unfamiliar, so it wasn’t an easy read. Involves sexual violence, the NY sex trade, the history of building in early 20th century New York, Freud and Jung, local politics and it’s corruptions, power, romance, adventure etc. Quite an achievement to write such a book. Lots of interesting characters too, some more believable than others. I wasn’t disappointed.

Dr younger is narrating Freud visits America with Jung & Ferenczi. Someone kills a girlEveryone gets involved in the investigation. Liked the explanations of Freuds theories and the division with Jung. Really interesting. Also like the side tracking into Hamlet and bridge construction. Had to concentrate when murderer was revealed to get head around how the detective figured it. Wouldn’t recommend as a thriller, but certainly I found it interesting.

A protege of Freud is given the job of psychoanalyzing a 17-year-old attack victim, getting him involved in a murder mystery. The psychoanalysis sounds authentic for the times but, except at one critical point, adds only a very little to anyone's understanding of anything. Most of the work is done by an underestimated police detective. The details of the crime, however, are so labyrinthine as to strain credibility.

It was ok. I found it super confusing most of the time, probably because of the Freud/Jung parts. I'm still not 100% sure that that "main theme but not the main theme" was really necessary. I suspect that the actual murder mystery would have been far more engaging without the distractions offered by the battles for and against schools of psychoanalysis. I did enjoy the parts focused on the crime aspects and there were some surprises.

I do not like books concerning sexual assaults. Was interested in some of the true history within the story - considering I only read to page 93, plus the author's afterword. One example that shocked me was the "Astor Place Riot." Could not believe that more than 20 people were killed - supposedly all because of a rivalry between Shakespearean actors in 1849. Would have liked to learn more about the feud between Freud and Jung, but will have to search nonfiction to do so.

This book was awful, I don't even know why I finished it. It felt like there was three completely different stories that the author wanted to tell and so they had to force them to connect somehow. I kept losing track of the characters and couldn't remember who the side characters were because they were not memorable or even described well. I would not ever read this book again or recommend it

It was an exciting book, but I almost gave up on it about halfway through. At a certain point it became a little too complicated for me. The main story was difficult enough without having to add the storyline about the triumviate. But I got past that point fairly quickly and in the end I was happy to say I kept on reading.

I walked with Freud, and actually, I attended his lectures on neurosis. For some years he vanished and when he rerurned it wasn't for so long. Eventually, he walked on into the distance never to be seen again. Though I learned much from this man. The one thing I will always remember is the dinner night. That was when I sat with Dr. Freud and Enstein.

The plot was interesting enough for me too keep reading. But I don't know why Freud, Jung, Brill and Ferenczi were in the book. Cut them out and the plot still remains the same. There was also a disconnect between certain chunks of the book and it was very text bookish at times. So much for the mystrey to happiness and the meaning of life. Would make a nice movie though.

I discovered this book by accident, having not heard of the author before.The only thing from the back cover that intrigued me was Freud.But man o man, was this a brilliant book. Sure. The way the author has stitched a man of the stature of Freud in this fantastic make belief crime thriller. Superb.A must read for historical fiction fans.

I love this kind of book, which has some historic persons in a fictional but historic setting, where you get the idea of getting to know the actual historic figures better. Plus the bonus of a mystery/ thriller, some psychology. Well written. What's not to like. It's very good but not totally amazing though.

This is book is the epitome of revelation and insight into the human mind. The management of sensitive topics and incorporation of conflicting view points were superb. Aside from that, the plot was also intriguing and the descriptions life-like and vivid! This is a must-read for psychology students!

The book started on a good note, took a dip somewhere quarter way through, and it picked up until the end that I can't put it down after several chapters in.I'm drawn to Freud's and Jung's characters because somehow I feel like it shows a different facet of these two psychologists (even if it's just fictional).

A very clever and well written book but is not an easy read. You have to be focused to follow the different storylines going on whilst making the psychologist in me try to psychoanalyse the characters in the book at the same time. Perhaps if I read this book at a different time when I wasn't so busy and could give it more of my attention I may have understood and enjoyed it more.

It was the opening of this book that changed my perspective on life, Through this book's opening I became a man"to find meaning, one must relive the past however dark and live for the future, however uncertain... Nature dangles happiness and meaning infront of us, insisting that we only choose one"

Overall, it was a well written book with intriguing characters and story. Other than I think it could have ended 100 pages sooner, I enjoyed the book. It just felt too drawn out near the end. However, the story was interesting with non-fictional and fictional based characters, and a decent twist to finish off the suspense. I'd still recommend it!

As a admirer of Freud and fictionalised history, the idea of putting him into a murder mystery scenario, whilst the breakdown of his relationship with Carl Jung played out, appealed greatly as a premise. And I enjoyed the end result. The writer knows the respective character's ideas and works well enough that you feel like what plays out is truly what happened. Happily recommend.

Very clever story. Romps along at a good pace. Having Freud and Jung around in 1909 US to help a detective and doctor (Freudian) solve a murder is intriguing. Another book finally read. Was given to me by a work colleague whilst on first assignment to Craiova Romania - 12 years ago😂Well I suppose life got in the way. Need to check out more by this author.

It's a mixture of Shakespear and Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung as the main characters but the story is not cohesive. The title "interpretation of murder" doesn't reflect the content of the book. It's more of a detective story plus some mini-stories of Sigmund Freud. A bit confusing and less entertaining than I thought.

I studied Freud in college and was a fan so this book seemed right up my alley. I enjoyed the story and the way it was presented. I also liked the true elements mixed in with the fiction. After finishing the book I was interested to read up on the characters to learn more. A good read. Kept my interest in reading more to see what happens next.

I didn't love it. I didn't hate it though either.Not a read that I feel wasted my time. So I guess there's that.I feel like despite all the attempts at an organized novel, it still felt very sloppy and unorganized.I did appreciate how the perspective changes builds in suspense and small cliff hangers.In all, I fell like there is just too much going on.

Great book, includes Freud and Carl Jung. Consists of looking for this murderer with few leads. When they come to a conclusion the story completely flips and turns direction. I learned a little about Freud and Jung in this read. It's not just about detectives solving a murder, it's also about psychoanalysis on a patient which also flips. Great read, eventually worth it!

another memory dredged up... rememebr reading this freshman year of high school and it's been haunting me... something about freud coming to America but i barely remember anything else. Feels like a fever dream. all I remember is i read it mostly during school or with a flashlight in my "nest" aka I slept on a couch pushed facing the wall.

4/5 stars! What a great near Halloween read! This had a film noir feel at times. The perfect time to read this! At times, I didn’t like how the author would go off on random subjects. I didn’t need a chapter of building history. I get he was trying to set the scene, give background for the setting. But I thought it was monotonous. The overall story was great though

Unfortunately this book didn't do it for me at all; I found it confusing in places and completely long winded. I ended up missing a huge chunk out just to read the last couple of chapters; it felt like pulling teeth I'm afraid.

I read a book by his wife for book club last month and she mention that her husband had written a book. I wanted to see the difference in writing styles. I found it fascinating as a historical fiction. I can't wrap my mind around Freud theory's though.

Clever plotting, interesting characters from wholly invented to historically based, and convincing settings make the U.S. introduction of Sigmund Freud's psychoanalysis in 1909 New York both messily human and foreign seeming.

I wanted to like this book because I enjoy historicals. This was fine until half way through when the main police detective does something very stupid. I didn't throw the book cross the room but I was tempted. Then the author lose control of the plot and the whole thing comes a convoluted mess.

Excellent! I was a little worried that this book might not live up to the plaudits it received but these worries were to be proved without substance. A truly enthralling page-turner - will keep you guessing.

Interesting premise of working Freud into a fiction novel. It was a great whodunit, and some of the psychological aspects of the characters were interesting too. Not sure if I'll rush out to buy the next in the series though.

Apart from the fact that everything to do with psychotherapy was misunderstood and trivialised - it strikes me that this is not too bad. I enjoyed it - but it did annoy me about the clear misunderstanding of psychotherapy.

It's taken a while but I've finally sat down and finished it. It's a bit sad as this was an intellectually challenging read as much as entertaining. Complex psychology and historical fiction - what's not to like?

This is historical fiction based on the only trip Freud made to the US. It centers on a murder mystery, Freud and his associates, and NYC during the early 1900's. I found it interesting reading about the city and how Freud reacted to the events at the time.

An interesting story which almost had me gripped all the way through. However, I unfortunately found the ending a bit disappointing and had predicted a number of elements before getting that far.That said, I did enjoy the reading and would recommend it.

Freud in America and a couple of murders. Contains a lot of interesting philosophy (or psychology), and great characters. The conclusion was a bit to incredulous for me, but it was very interesting reading about how Brooklyn Bridge was constructed and built.

I picked this book up because the blurb mentioned Sigmund Freud and the cover said "10th Anniversary Edition - Million Copy Bestseller". I wasn't going to pass up a book like that, and I'm glad I didn't. A very interesting, fast-paced read without even a single dull moment. Loved every buy of it.

I really liked this book. The story was well crafted, although it seems to stall a little just after the start. Freud and Jung seem like plot point delivery mechanisms more than anything else, but it was a very enjoyable read and the ending was not predictable.

I really struggled with this book , it was like two different stories one about Freud and America and the other , Littlemore and solving the murders the only redeeming thing about this book is the Littlemore character

Really liked this book - different to what I normally read and yes there are quite a few words that I had never heard of before but I very much enjoyed the book and the last 100 pages were very good! Certainly didn’t see the reality coming!

Somewhat unbalanced -lack of strong female characters. Almost all female characters are either one dimensional, weak, or seriously psychologically flawed and unbalanced. No strong, or simply "normal" women except for one and she hardly figures in the story. Otherwise an interesting story.

I'd give it a 3.5 if I could. I think it's an interesting book. The "psychology" element was very good and engrossing, I enjoyed it very much. It's light and comfortable to read, an easy read I must say. A nice novel to read if you're interested in murder mystery and psychology. happy reads :)
