The underlying storyline was great by keeping you guessing. Great twist at the end. I got lost a lot with the psychoanalysis babble. It was great to read about real people from history, interwoven into the story

It took some time to get into this, but once I was captured, I was hooked. Here was a riddle, wrapped inside an enigma. The twists and turns will make you re-think our relationships with others and the way we respond.

Rubenfeld did a great job painting with words New York in the time of Freud. His seemingly effortless descriptions helped to make this an immersive read with a great plot. It however felt that the plot was slightly too lengthy for my liking. All in all a great book though!

Six out of ten.In the early 20th century, Sigmund Freud made his one and only visit to the US. In later years, he often talked of his dislike for America and the savages who lived there. This is the story of what happened during his visit.A decent thriller but slightly trashy.

Clever enough for some time but then the plot got totally out of hand. If you love Freudian psychology you'll like this book. Curious writing style. The narration went from first person to third and back again several times and for no apparent reason.

Between 2 and 3 stars.(Review for a book I read a while ago)I enjoyed parts of it. The snippets of Freud were enjoyable, it added some pizzaz to the book. But it's one of those books I read fairly quick. It is enjoyable in that sense. I didn't really think about it. It took my mind off things. But sometimes books like that are a welcome change.

DNF. Life’s too short for bad books when there are a plethora of gems to read. This book and zero character development, streams of pointless filler and multiple confusing story lines. Not for me, Thanks.

Great book with a lot of twists. I loved how many things were inspired by true events and conversations. It's also a great intro into Freud's and Jung's theories. A very good read for those who like a mix of history, crime and early 20th century US.

A well written and researched book. It took me a long time to read the book however I did enjoy it. It combines historical events, with Freudian psychoanalysis and an intriguing murder thriller. Lots of twists and turns.

Found this book a bit of a slog. although story and plot ok - sometimes a bit too clever. The sexism was very tiresome (I know he was trying to recreate the attitudes of the time) but some more original descriptive phrases for attractive young women might have been refreshing.

Not my book - suggested by my husband who really liked it, what I can't stand is stories about real people that are completely fictional. I also found the writing a little too detailed and got bored reading. I never leave a book unfinished so I persevered - it took me a long time to read this.

Once I got to the halfway point this Murder Mystery took off. I struggled immensely through the first half of this book. It’s twisty and dark and makes you think about Psychoanalysis in a whole new light - oh, and there’s tons of Shakespeare! ⭐️⭐️⭐️

The book began thus: “There is no mystery to happiness…” Well, there is no mystery in the book either. Except the reasons for even writing one that is so shallow in places where it should have been deep.The book begins on an extravagant note to anyone who has read the back cover of the book. The abstract of the book sounds grand, makes it appealing and makes you wish you’d get through it in no time. But, alas, the story fizzles out just like the carbon dioxide of a just-opened soda bottle.And so we enter ‘The Interpretation of Murder‘ with Dr. Stratham Younger, the narrator, waiting at a harbor for a certain gentleman, who the reader hopes is going to play a huge role in the book, Sigmund Freud. The description, of the unrest at the harbor and the arrival of Freud with a party, is all very well. A few more pages into the book, we are told that a girl (Elizabeth Riverford) is murdered; she is donned in almost nothing and has grotesque marks on her body; all very well too. And it makes the reader wish that there is a good reason for someone going after her throat in such a romantic fashion. Too bad, that the reason is not a very good one.Sigmund Freud arrives in early 20th century New York to deliver lectures at Clark University. I might add though, the description of the Big Apple in that era was very vivid. As it does happen in most murder mysteries, the timing of the murder and the arrival of Freud on American soil, cause Freud to get involved in the investigation. (This one is a no-brainer; you ought to guess it while you’re reading.) What is a little tiresome is the wait for Freud to enter the investigation, and add that little spark, to what is until at this point of time in the book, a wayside murder. Sadly, Freud just plays, what our readers have likened, a ‘Dumbledore to Harry’ to Dr. Stratham Younger in the book; and nothing more. He comes in when Younger needs a little help, he chips in his two pence to what Younger has discovered, and goes back into the wings.The second time, the killer fails to kill a certain Miss Nora Acton, and she proves to be the only witness who can be interrogated to nail down the murderer, albeit with a lost voice. Miss Acton can’t seem to remember anything from that night and neither is she able to speak. Thanks to a lot of convoluted twists in the book and some added masala by the author, Miss Acton is being resorted to psychological treatment by Dr. Younger to determine more about the killer.Simply the story is this:Nora Acton was tortured, but not killed, by Mr. Killer who has already killed another girl- She has lost her voice – Dr. Younger is brought in to treat her – Freud is helping Younger as and when he can – A certain Mr. Littlemore is investigating this case on behalf of the Police Department of New York – A certain Mr. and Mrs. Banwell enter the scene, as the building in which the murder takes place belongs to them (They are also affiliated to the Actons) – Younger and Littlemore eventually solve the case.At the mention of Mr. Littlemore, we have to stop a bit and give Littlemore the credit he deserves. By general consensus, he is THE finest and only lovable character in the book. Very measured, smart and a quick thinker- just like the detectives you are damned to like. One of our readers, Hardik Kothare, says about Littlemore, “My favourite character was Jimmy Littlemore. One of the reasons is his ability ‘to get a girl’ immediately…how could he do it? Damn! I am jealous! Haha.” Yes, he is undoubtedly a high point in the book. And whilst reading the garbled story, you find yourself hoping he would jump in and save the falling-apart story line.Some other mentions that the book review is incomplete without:The author has used the Oedipus Complex as the base for the book. He uses it to explain what’s going on with Nora and that immature mind of hers. Not only Nora, the author has also explained the reasons why Hamlet behaves like he does, on the basis of the Oedipus. (Yes, Hamlet, the one sketched by the Bard)That portion is a little stirring. Just a little. Rubenfeld has struggled with the Oedipus all along the book. And come to think of it, the book was based on the theory.A certain high of the book is Dr. Stratham Younger’s theory that most great inventions took place at the turn of a century. It makes you sit up and read while the rest of the reading is so tiring and forced.Once again, the description of Mrs. Clara Banwell was another small jump in the book, and how she is with Nora through here treatment on and off.Carl Jung arrives with Sigmund Freud and his character is totally wasted. Could have done without it.As a Bollywood measure, a group of three men calling themselves the Triumvirate enter the scene. They behave like they are going to pull off a stunt, but they don’t quite do anything as such. Could have done without it too.To wind up, one can say that there is nothing you take away from the book. It is a sluggish read. For those who have read Freud, it is just an overview of what the man was. They story is not gripping and neither is it educational for those who have not read Freud.-Sameen
To be fair, this book has some smart plot twists and the odd laugh out loud moment, but basically hokum.
freud is choked by his own theories. meanwhile, a murder mystery looms in the minds of its characters.
Just a really good page turnerIntellectual without being a lecture Highly recommended
Found and read the second book first. You don't have to read them in order. Both books great historical information as well as a good mystery. Hopefully the author is working on a third.
Really enjoyed this murder mystery. Real, historical characters and locations, combined with a tantalizing and satisfying murder mystery?? Yes, please!! Loved this!
Really enjoyed this, the 2 separate sides of the story were balanced really well - I didn't think either one was neglected.
Started well but with too many characters and different plots it became mixed up and hard to follow.
Good fun. Well written and I particularly liked the continual analyses and references to Hamlet and his "To be" soliloquy.
Even skimming and reading the end didn't help it make sense.... I suspect that's Freudian
Real page-turner. I devoured this. Funny, mysterious, very fast-paced and a great story. What more could you want? Freud's in it too!
Average but interesting
Great book. Enjoyed it.
Execellent and riveting . Everything in a historical crime drama
I guess it was ok and easy to read but I cannot say I really enjoyed the read that much.
Well written. Enjoyable plotline. I liked that even though Jung and Freud are characters they are not used as the predominant individual which made it more acceptable as a work of fiction.
I found this a page turner set in an interesting era with the background of early psychiatry.
A really enjoyable murder mystery set in New York in 1909.
There were some boring parts, but overall it was very entertaining and clever.
Seriously enjoyed this book! Found it really Sherlock Holmes esque...with the Freudian angle. Definitely recommend if love old school crime novel with twists and turns
great

A very problematic read... all the elements of a great novel, but not worth it.

Clever.

Spectacularly written and hauntingly thrilling.
2 1/2 really- kind of inconsistent through the story

Very rad

Very interesting!

Found this very clever and gripping. Also drawn to the portrait of New York as the industrialisation boom was kicking off.

Great read and appreciated the epilogue at the end :)

three stars just for the plot . witty and unpredictable

Interesting story

I found this book very interesting and fascinating, the story, the characters and the thought and importance of the psycoanalist!
I liked it but I don't understand the plot. I confused with the plot twist the character's motive.... But I got many things from this book like the mind of murder, psychology things, hypnosis, etc.
Forgot how much I enjoyed historical fictions. Exceptional research.

This book had all the features of a good mystery, but unfortunately for me it fell a bit flat. I was so close to DNFing it but I did finish it and I think the twist at the end was great- which is what made me give this book 3/5 stars.It started off really slow and think this is what let the book down, because between the flip of first and third person, and the long winded backgrounds of the characters or New York, I found myself getting lost. The inclusion of Sigmund Freud and his team/fellow psychoanalysts was an interesting take on a mystery- but he wasn’t used. He was there to give advice to the main character, like a father figure, or to be vilified by Carl Jung. For someone who is such an important figure in this form of science it was disappointing to see him pushed into the background. It was also disappointing to discover the murder wasn’t actually a murder at all. This book definitely didn’t meet expectations but I had never heard of it and I was intrigued which is why I picked it up in the first place. I did start to enjoy it towards the latter half of the book, even if the start did bore me, and I’m glad I eventually finished it. I would take this book with a pinch of salt. It may not be everyone’s cup of tea and is a little misleading in places. 3/5 stars.
Unbelievably well written. While not my normal pick, I have no regrets. Would read and recommend this book 1000 times over.
It was ok. It felt like the historic aspect of Freud and co. was forced at times to make it historic fiction.
Funnily enough, I wasn't a fan of the start or the beginning, BUT THE MIDDLE WAS GREAT ahah and I wish they would have made the last scene more emotional but, it was good anyways!
Good concept, largely unattractive characters. If the misogyny and lack of medical ethics is true, psychoanalysis gets a bad press here.
A wonderfully written mystery. It will hook you from the beginning and not let you go. For all of the mystery and psychology lovers out there this is an amazing read.
Dry. Prosaic.
Murder, mystery with Freud and Jung. Ok for first half, then tails off badly.
4.5 rounded up
Full of athmosphere, history and analytical psychology this thriller hit into my heart. I liked it very much indeed.
A bit contrived. Too much Freud. Too clever for me! But quite enjoyed it.

I had a whole evening where I finished the second half of this book. I really liked it up to about page 250. It's historical setting was fascinating and the plot build up working really well for me. The second part was equivalent to a literary version of Keystone Cops. More plot twists and development than necessary. Sadly for me I lost at that halfway stage, that sense of real enjoyment in completing a book.
My favourite book, highly recommended

This book is not my favourite book in the world but I was easy enough to read and a good concept. Note: This was originally written on 2/5/2011 Marvelous fiction based on an ingenious realignment of historical fact. In my opinion, this book deserves far more acclaim than it has thus far received.

Interesting, but almost barely worth commenting on. Psycho-babble.I decided to read the book before moving on to No. 2 in the series, just to get some ideas about the author and what to expect. It seems like the author is heavy into H.G. Wells, Arthur Conan Doyle and Shakespeare, besides being an expert on Freudian psychtherapy, is the impression I received.The second book is more interesting to me because of the terrorist bombing angle, and the obvious correlations to the recent Boston Marathon incident (although the book was written beforehand). Turns out these kinds of anarchistic doings with explosives have occurred many times in the past, in Los Angeles, in Chicago, and in New York if you study over history (the author gives brief mention to these other incidents as well and you can research them further on your own), and not for the first time in 2001 on 911 as one had been led to believe. Rubenfeld can make his stories interesting, even if he can't rise above the times or attitudes he encounters during those periods. This one seemed very illogical to me, for the simple reason that it involves a ruse. At the start of the book, a male character is stalking a female one, but it turns out to be a hoax (actually it is a reverse of this, if I read the book correctly). Attempting to put together all the end explanations was a bigger mental chore than was warranted for me. One merely accepts the truth and seeming angle that was put forth earlier in the book. Even though the guilty parties are finally found out and brought to justice, the carnage has been done. The book can't walk away from this fact, and that makes it a tragic ending. Not even Hamlet could sort this one out. There seems to be too many subplots that are unconnected, which creates a sense of confusion. The evil trio of shadowy agents in America, opposed to Freud's new pyschotherapy theories, that are suspected of having somehow been involved in the murder turn out to have nothing to do with either this murder that never actually happened, or with the other shadowy one that actually did. Huh? You better be prepared for a let down here. None of this is going to make perfect sense to the reader, but very contrived for emotional gusher effects. The reported murder is so sexually implicit and disgusting in brutality that it leaves the reader no where else to turn to. Finding the murderer then becomes an exercise in trying out some of Freud's theories on a second person attacked by the same demented sex deviant but who survived it with only burns and cuts. She has temporarily lost her memory of the attack, and any would be knowledge of the attacker. Can her memory be restored through psychotherapeutic methods? Here again, the woman's memory suddenly comes back on its own, and she is hostile towards being a patient rather than a victim. Why set the scene of a man stalking someone early in the book, if no man is literally stalking someone and the main suspect has an air-tight alibi of having been with the mayor during the time of the purported murder? It is the fear of what might happen in the future rather than what has already happened that eventually makes sense of the events, and that so disturb the reader's sensibilities when the hoax is revealed to be a skillfully worked out plot by the two women involved. Apparently, one of the women dressed up as a man to put everyone off the trail.  The book did contain some exciting scenes, such as when Littlemore and Younger, detective and doctor duo (reminiscent of Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson), pursue evidence that has been moved underground or underwater (H. G. Wells inspired adventure). Their artificial air chamber used to go down below is rapidly filling with water, and the race is on to see if they can get back to the surface in time. To heighten the suspense, the doctor character is missing for quite some time, and suspected to have transpired. This turns out not to be the case, but the evidence that the detective and doctor went down to find is not conclusive, merely some clothing items and not the missing body itself, which raises the question of the importance of that section at all. That's the kind of problems I found in reading the book. Nothing seemed to add up until the very end, and then it all seemed anti-climatic, with all the air released from the balloon in a sudden pin prick moment that was not what one was expecting. Freud's Oedipal leanings are shown to be false, or at least misleading. The father envies the son, more than the son envies the father, according to the narrator, who had been one of Freud's followers until he received his contradictory revelations during the course of the novel. But does it matter who is envying who? It's a bit confusing, as I said.
I thoroughly enjoyed this book based on a little history, sometimes stretched a bit but it made it all the more interesting. I look forward to reading more of this series.
